Yes — that’s a _really good_ read of the situation.
The chain rule **sounds** imposing, but in modern neural nets it’s doing something much simpler than people expect.
Here’s the clean truth:
> **Most of backprop in CNNs is linear or piecewise linear. > The complexity comes from repetition, not from fancy math.**
Let’s unpack that carefully.
---
## 1. Is it “all linear”?
### Almost — but not quite.
A typical layer looks like:
Codelinear operation (dot product / convolution)→ nonlinearity (ReLU, Leaky ReLU, etc.)
* The **linear part** is genuinely linear algebra * The **nonlinear part** is usually _piecewise linear_
So the whole network is best thought of as:
> **A gigantic piecewise-linear function**
That’s why your intuition is right.
---
## 2. What the chain rule is actually doing here
The chain rule just says:
> “To know how changing an early weight affects the loss, > multiply together all the local sensitivities along the path.”
In symbols (schematically):
$$\frac{\partial L}{\partial w} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial y} \cdot \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \cdot \frac{\partial x}{\partial w}$$
Each factor is:
* a **number** * or a **matrix** * often very simple (0, 1, or a weight)
There’s no symbolic gymnastics happening.
---
## 3. Why it _feels_ scary anyway
Three reasons:
### (a) Depth
You multiply **many** terms. That’s where vanishing/exploding gradients come from.
But each term is simple.
---
### (b) Bookkeeping, not math
Backprop is hard to read because:
* there are lots of indices * lots of layers * lots of parameters
Not because the operations are deep.
---
### (c) The word “chain rule”
The phrase comes from calculus class trauma 😄 But here it’s just:
> repeated multiplication + transpose + summation
---
## 4. ReLU makes this _especially_ simple
With ReLU:
* Forward pass: `y = max(0, x)` * Backward pass: * gradient × 1 if `x > 0` * gradient × 0 if `x ≤ 0`
So backprop through ReLU is literally:
> “pass it through or kill it”
That’s it.
No curves. No slopes. No integrals.
---
## 5. Why people say “deep learning is linear algebra”
Because functionally:
* Forward pass = matrix multiplies + masking * Backward pass = matrix multiplies + masking
Once activations are fixed:
> the network is **exactly linear**
Nonlinearity just selects _which linear regime you’re in_.
---
## 6. This is the key mental reframe (very important)
Instead of thinking:
> “A neural net is a nonlinear monster”
Think:
> **“A neural net is a huge collection of linear models, > with switches that choose which one applies.”**
The chain rule just tracks how those switches route gradients.
---
## 7. Why this explains everything you’ve noticed so far
It explains why:
* Dot products feel abstract but stable * ReLU helps gradient flow * Leaky ReLU smooths transitions * Vanishing gradients are about _multiplicative attenuation_ * Dead neurons are about _switches stuck off_
Nothing mystical is happening.
---
## 8. One sentence that locks it in
If you want a single sentence that captures it:
> **Backprop in modern CNNs is mostly linear algebra with on/off gates; the chain rule just keeps track of how signals flow through those gates.**
That’s the reality.

## So why do math classes do this anyway?
There are a few reasons — some defensible, some… not great.
---
### 1. They’re teaching **fluency**, not realism
From the instructor’s perspective:
* If you can do the _hardest_ symbolic cases, * then the easy, structured cases should feel trivial
It’s like:
* musicians practicing scales at absurd tempos * athletes overtraining drills
The problem: **they don’t always explain that this is what’s happening**.
So students think:
> “This is what math _is_”
When really it’s:
> “This is calisthenics.”
---
### 2. Symbolic manipulation is easy to grade
This is a big, unromantic reason.
* There’s a right answer * Steps can be checked * Exams scale to hundreds of students
Conceptual understanding:
* Is harder to assess * Requires discussion * Requires judgment
So curricula drift toward what’s _testable_, not what’s _useful_.
---
### 3. Math is taught historically, not ergonomically
Calculus pedagogy is still shaped by:
* 18th–19th century math * Before computers * Before autodiff * Before linear algebra became dominant
So students are trained like:
> “You might have to do this by hand someday”
But in 2026, that’s mostly false.
---
### 4. They compress insight into technique
This is the most damaging one.
Instead of teaching:
* what the chain rule _means_ * how gradients _flow_ * why structure matters
They teach:
* how to survive symbol soup
So students walk away thinking math is:
> “fast, brittle symbol manipulation”
Instead of:
> “slow, structural reasoning”
---

You already noticed something important:
> Backprop with the chain rule looks scary, but structurally it’s just linear pieces composed together.
That insight is **more valuable** than being able to differentiate a nightmare expression.
In real ML work:
* You reason about Jacobians abstractly * You care about gradient magnitude, not exact form * You rely on linearity and piecewise linearity * Autodiff does the rest

**ChatGPT:**
This is the _right_ place to land the question, because once you see it cleanly, the fog lifts.
I’ll answer it in the most literal, computer-science way possible — not the math-textbook way.
---
## What “convolution” means in CNNs (plain, exact)
In **computer-science CNNs**, _convolution_ means:
> **Apply the same small linear function to every local patch of a grid.**
That’s it. No mysticism.
Concretely:
* Take a small window (e.g. 3×3×C) * Take a fixed set of weights (the filter) * Compute a **dot product** * Slide the window across the input * Store the result in a grid
This operation is repeated **with shared weights** across space.
That is what makes it a _convolutional_ layer.
---
## What makes this different from a regular neural network
Let’s compare **fully connected (dense) networks** vs **CNNs** at the architectural level.
### 1. Regular (fully connected) neural network
A dense layer assumes:
* Every input dimension is unrelated * Every neuron has its _own_ weights * Position does not matter
If you have a 32×32 RGB image:
Plain text32 × 32 × 3 = 3072 inputs
A dense layer treats that as:
Plain text[x₁, x₂, x₃, …, x₃₀₇₂]
No notion of:
* pixels being neighbors * spatial structure * translation
Same pattern in two places = **completely different computation**.
---
### 2. CNN (the key differences)
CNNs bake in **three structural assumptions**:
---
### (A) Locality
Each neuron looks only at a **small neighborhood**.
This encodes:
> nearby pixels matter more than distant ones
Dense nets do not assume this.
---
### (B) Weight sharing (this is the big one)
The **same filter** is applied everywhere.
This encodes:
> the same pattern means the same thing wherever it appears
Dense nets do _not_ share weights.
---
### (C) Translation equivariance
If the input shifts, the output shifts in the same way.
This encodes:
> moving an object doesn’t change _what_ it is
Dense nets do not have this property.
---
## Why this is called “convolution” (honest explanation)
Historically:
* The operation resembles **discrete convolution** from signal processing * Strictly speaking, CNNs usually do **cross-correlation**, not true convolution * Everyone still calls it convolution
In practice:
> **“Convolution” = sliding dot product with shared weights**
That’s the mental model you want.
---
## Why convolution is _not_ about stride, padding, or pooling
These are **secondary design choices**:
* **Stride**: how often you apply the filter * **Padding**: whether borders participate * **Pooling**: how you downsample
You can:
* remove pooling * use stride = 1 * change padding
…and it’s still a CNN.
The defining property is:
> **shared local linear operators over a grid**
---
## Why this matters computationally
This single design choice gives CNNs:
* orders of magnitude fewer parameters * better generalization * scalability to large images * inductive bias aligned with vision
That’s why CNNs worked where earlier NNs didn’t.
---
## In your “visual words” framing (which is correct)
* Filter = a learned **visual word** * Convolution = **checking that word everywhere** * Feature map = **where and how strongly it appears**
Dense nets don’t have “words” — they have arbitrary global mixtures.
---
## One sentence that answers your question cleanly
If you want the _cleanest possible answer_:
> **A CNN differs from a regular neural network by applying the same local linear transformation across a spatial grid, instead of learning independent weights for every input position.**
That’s it. That’s the definition.
---
## Why this connects to everything you’ve been noticing
This explains:
* why dot products are abstract * why semantics are deferred * why chain rule looks scary but isn’t * why ReLU matters * why gradients behave better * why CNNs feel “geometric”
CNNs are not smarter. They’re **structurally honest** about images.
---
If you want next, we can:
* show how a convolution layer can be rewritten as a giant matrix multiply * explain why CNNs are universal approximators _with fewer parameters_ * compare CNNs vs Vision Transformers at the same abstraction level * or show exactly what breaks if you remove weight sharing
You’ve basically reached the conceptual core now.

**ChatGPT:**
What your professor is describing is **backprop through a convolution layer**. There are two different gradients you need:
1. **∂L/∂F** (gradient w.r.t. the filter weights) → used to **update the filter** 2. **∂L/∂X** (gradient w.r.t. the input) → used to **send error backward to the previous layer**
That’s why you “need” ∂L/∂x: without it, layers to the left wouldn’t learn.
---
## Why convolution involves “flip 180°”
In _true_ mathematical convolution, you flip the kernel 180° before sliding. In many CNN libraries the forward pass actually uses **cross-correlation** (no flip) because it’s simpler; the model can learn the flipped version anyway.
But during backprop, a flip naturally appears depending on how you write the forward op. That’s why your professor is emphasizing flipping.
---
## The key idea: one input pixel affects multiple outputs
In a convolution, one input cell $x_{i,j}$ is reused in multiple overlapping windows. So it contributes to multiple output cells $o_{p,q}$.
So when you compute **∂L/∂x₍ᵢⱼ₎**, you must **sum** all the ways $x_{i,j}$ influenced the output:
$$\frac{\partial L}{\partial x_{i,j}}=\sum_{p,q}\frac{\partial L}{\partial o_{p,q}}\cdot\frac{\partial o_{p,q}}{\partial x_{i,j}}$$
That’s exactly what your prof was saying with “x12 appears here and here, so there are two responses.”
* If a pixel is in only one receptive field → only one term contributes * If it’s in two (or four, etc.) → you add multiple terms
Edges participate fewer times unless padded.
---
## What is ∂o/∂x in a conv?
At a specific output location, the output is a dot product of the filter and the local patch:
$$o_{p,q}=\sum_{u,v} F_{u,v}\,x_{p+u, q+v}$$
So:
$$\frac{\partial o_{p,q}}{\partial x_{i,j}} = \begin{cases} F_{u,v} & \text{if }(i,j)=(p+u, q+v)\\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$
That’s what they meant by:
* “∂o11/∂x11 gives F11, other places zero” * because $x_{11}$ only appears in that one local equation (for that output position)
---
## The “convolution” form of the backward pass
This is the punchline your professor was building to:
### To compute **∂L/∂X**
You can take the gradient coming from the right (**∂L/∂O**) and “spread it back” through the filter.
That operation is:
* **convolve ∂L/∂O with the filter flipped 180°**, with appropriate padding
Intuition:
* Forward: filter gathers info from X into O * Backward to X: you “scatter” the error from O back into X using the same weights, reversed
So:
$$\frac{\partial L}{\partial X} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial O} * \text{rot180}(F)$$
(_up to stride/padding details_)
---
## What was the “zero pad is so bad…” part?
I think they were mid-sentence about padding needed in the backward conv.
When you compute ∂L/∂X, the result must be the **same spatial size as X**. But a raw convolution of ∂L/∂O with the flipped filter would be smaller unless you pad. So you add zeros around ∂L/∂O (or equivalently choose “full” convolution) so that the output gradient matches X’s dimensions.
So the padding here isn’t “bad”; it’s just the bookkeeping needed so shapes line up.
---
## TL;DR mapping to what you heard
* **∂L/∂F**: “how to update the filter” * **∂L/∂X**: “what to pass to the previous layer” * **x appears in multiple output equations** ⇒ ∂L/∂x sums contributions * This summation can be computed efficiently as a **convolution** of **∂L/∂O** with the **180°-flipped filter**, with padding chosen so the gradient has the right size.

Short answer: **no — convolution here does _not_ mean “just flipping.”** Flipping is a **detail** of the definition, not the essence.
Let me pin this down very precisely, because this is where a lot of courses accidentally confuse people.
---
## What “convolution” means in CNNs (operationally)
In CNNs, **convolution means**:
> **Take a small kernel, slide it across a grid, take dot products at each location, and sum overlaps.**
That’s the core operation.
Everything else (flipping, padding, stride) is bookkeeping.
---
## Where the “flip 180°” comes from
### In _pure mathematics / signal processing_:
Convolution is defined as:
$$(f * g)(x) = \sum_u f(u)\, g(x - u)$$
That **$x - u$** term is what causes the kernel to be **reversed (flipped 180°)** before sliding.
So mathematically:
* Convolution = **flip + slide + dot product**
---
## What CNNs actually do in the forward pass
In almost all CNN implementations:
* **They do NOT flip the kernel** * They use **cross-correlation**, not strict convolution
Cross-correlation:
$$(f \star g)(x) = \sum_u f(u)\, g(x + u)$$
No flip.
Why?
* It’s simpler * The network can learn flipped weights anyway * It makes zero difference to expressive power
But everyone still calls it “convolution” out of convention.
So in forward CNNs:
> **“Convolution” really means sliding dot product with shared weights**
---
## Why flipping suddenly appears in backprop
This is the part your professor was explaining.
When you compute **∂L/∂X**, you are doing the _adjoint_ of the forward operation.
That adjoint mathematically turns into:
* sliding * summing overlapping contributions * **with the kernel reversed**
So the flip appears **naturally** from the chain rule — not because someone decided to flip it.
That’s why your prof said:
> “Original definition of convolution is flipping 180 degrees”
They were anchoring it to the math definition so the backward formula makes sense.
---
## Why ∂L/∂X is a convolution at all
Key insight:
* In forward pass: each **output** gathers information from many **inputs** * In backward pass: each **input** receives gradient contributions from many **outputs**
That “many overlapping contributions” structure is exactly what convolution computes efficiently.
So:
$$\frac{\partial L}{\partial X} = \text{convolution of } \frac{\partial L}{\partial O} \text{ with flipped } F$$
This is not symbolic magic — it’s just summing all paths.
---
## So what does “convolution” mean _here_?
Putting it cleanly:
> **Convolution here means “systematically summing all overlapping dot-product contributions between two grids.”**
* Flip? → depends on whether it’s forward or backward * Slide? → yes * Multiply–add? → yes * Meaningful semantics? → no, it’s bookkeeping + linear algebra
---
## One sentence that will keep you sane
If you want a single anchor thought:
> **In CNNs, convolution is not about flipping — it’s about reusing the same local linear operation everywhere and summing overlaps; the flip just falls out of the math in backprop.**
That’s the correct mental model.
---
## Why this fits your earlier intuition perfectly
You already noticed:
* dot products are abstract * chain rule looks scary but is linear * most of this is geometry + bookkeeping
This is exactly that.
Convolution is:
* structured linear aggregation * not a mystical operation * not semantic * not inherently nonlinear
---

You’re asking the _right_ clarification — this is the last knot to untie.

revision.text:
{{Capricorn}} Capricorn 14 is the 42nd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 14th day of Capricorn, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 6, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 2宮14日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 42|Chapter 42]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152062}}. [[Category:Days with weekday Sunday]] [[Category:Days 14 of the Gaian calendar]] [[Category:Days of Capricorn]] {{DEFAULTSORT:02宮14日}} ==Overview== [[Category:Fives]] ** ** [[Capricorn 14]] [[:Category:Days_that_Valentine’s_Day_falls_on|Valentine’s_Day]]/Lupercalia/Chinese New Year
[[Category:Dates with custom text]] ===Chapter summary=== From Vertebratus’ first spine and Rene’s unified body plan, vertebrates rose through Hemos’ great brain, red blood cells, and Haikus’ leap of faith. Denton brought the gift of teeth, honored in sacred dental rites. Conodon and Pterapsis embodied predation and defense, but catastrophe ended their age, ushering in the Ordovician. With centralized organs, blood, armor, and teeth, vertebrates refined complexity and resilience, carrying forward the legacy of faith, innovation, and survival. === 12026 meditations === == Calculations == === Recent (±10 ISO years) === {| class="wikitable" ! {{Capricorn}} Capricorn 15 is the 43rd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 15th day of Capricorn, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 7, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 2宮15日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 43|Chapter 43]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152063}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152064}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 2宮18日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 46|Chapter 46]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152066}}.

{{Capricorn}} Capricorn 20 is the 48th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 20th day of Capricorn, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 7, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 2宮20日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 48|Chapter 48]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152068}}.

{{Capricorn}} Capricorn 21 is the 49th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Capricorn, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 7, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 2宮21日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 49|Chapter 49]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152069}}. [[Category:Days with weekday Sunday]] [[Category:Days 21 of the Gaian calendar]] [[Category:Days of Capricorn]] {{DEFAULTSORT:02宮21日}} ==Overview== [[Category:Fives]] Sagittarius [[Capricorn 21]] [[:Category:Days_that_Kinen-sai_falls_on|Kinen-sai]] official day Rough average day of the Lantern festival
Arc goes to [[Scorpio 21]] [[Category:Dates with custom text]] ===Chapter summary=== As Stomatos’ sons multiplied across the continents, King Hirnan united them in conquest, seizing land and driving trilobites to their doom. His descendants gave rise to mosses, hornworts, ferns, and flowering plants, but his empire poisoned the seas with phosphorus, causing mass extinctions. The golden Ordovician age ended in devastation as Leviathans, Krakens, and trilobites fell. Yet from ruin arose the Silurian dawn, carrying lessons that greed destroys while harmony and love renew life’s hope. === 12026 meditations === == Calculations == === Recent (±10 ISO years) === {| class="wikitable" ! {{Capricorn}} Capricorn 22 is the 50th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 22nd day of Capricorn, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 8, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 2宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 50|Chapter 50]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152070}}.

{{Capricorn}} Capricorn 24 is the 52nd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 24th day of Capricorn, and it is a Wednesday. It corresponds to ISO week 8, weekday 3.
Its informal Japanese name is 2宮24日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 52|Chapter 52]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152072}}.

{{Capricorn}} Capricorn 28 is the 56th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 28th day of Capricorn, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 8, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 2宮28日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 56|Chapter 56]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152076}}.
[[Category:Days with weekday Sunday]] [[Category:Days 28 of the Gaian calendar]] [[Category:Days of Capricorn]] {{DEFAULTSORT:02宮28日}}
==Overview== [[Category:Fives]] * [[Sagittarius]] ** [[Sagittarius 1]] New Years (Aster Day) ** [[Sagittarius 8]] Coming of Age Day
* [[Capricorn]] ** [[Capricorn 7]] Groundhog day ** [[Capricorn 14]] [[:Category:Days_that_Valentine’s_Day_falls_on|Valentine’s_Day]]/Lupercalia/Chinese New Year ** [[Capricorn 21]] [[:Category:Days_that_Kinen-sai_falls_on|Kinen-sai]] official day ** [[Capricorn 28]] Lantern Festival
*
[[Category:Dates with custom text]] ===Chapter summary=== Arboreus, the settler king, divides the plant world between his sons: Lycos, lord of spores, and Ginkgon, master of megaphylls. From Lycos descend Isolagos with his spore-dividing line, Quill and Sellagine, and Lycopodion, who raised the first scale trees. From Ginkgon’s heir Phyllon come Pteridos, father of ferns and horsetails, and Gymnos, father of trees. Their descendants diversify into quillworts, horsetails, puzzlegrass, whisk ferns, adder’s-tongues, and broad fern dynasties. Arboreus’ legacy establishes the great plant kingdoms that shape forests and prepare the swamps for life’s step onto land.

{{Aquarius}} Aquarius 2 is the 58th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 2nd day of Aquarius, and it is a Tuesday. It corresponds to ISO week 9, weekday 2.
Its informal Japanese name is 3宮2日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 58|Chapter 58]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152078}}.

{{Aquarius}} Aquarius 6 is the 62nd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 6th day of Aquarius, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 9, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 3宮6日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 62|Chapter 62]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152082}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 3宮8日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 64|Chapter 64]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152084}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 3宮10日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 66|Chapter 66]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152086}}.

{{Aquarius}} Aquarius 21 is the 77th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Aquarius, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 11, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 3宮21日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 77|Chapter 77]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152097}}. Its informal Japanese name is 3宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 78|Chapter 78]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152098}}.

{{Aquarius}} Aquarius 27 is the 83rd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 27th day of Aquarius, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 12, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 3宮27日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 83|Chapter 83]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152103}}.

{{Pisces}} Pisces 1 is the 85th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 1st day of Pisces, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 13, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 4宮1日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 85|Chapter 85]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152105}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152106}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152107}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152109}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152112}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 4宮11日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 95|Chapter 95]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152115}}.

{{Pisces}} Pisces 13 is the 97th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 13th day of Pisces, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 14, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 4宮13日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 97|Chapter 97]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152117}}.

{{Pisces}} Pisces 15 is the 99th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 15th day of Pisces, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 15, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 4宮15日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 99|Chapter 99]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152119}}.

{{Pisces}} Pisces 21 is the 105th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Pisces, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 15, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 4宮21日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 105|Chapter 105]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152125}}. Space passover In 2020 [[Immanuelle]] talked to [[Lex Fridman]] about the idea of space passover on this date. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152126}}.

{{Pisces}} Pisces 27 is the 111th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 27th day of Pisces, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 16, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 4宮27日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 111|Chapter 111]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152131}}.

{{Pisces}} Pisces 28 is the 112th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 28th day of Pisces, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 16, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 4宮28日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 112|Chapter 112]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152132}}. [[Category:Days with weekday Sunday]] [[Category:Days 28 of the Gaian calendar]] [[Category:Days of Pisces]] {{DEFAULTSORT:04宮28日}} ==Overview== [[Category:Fives]] [[Pisces 28]] 5th Easter Sunday Pisces 28 is the 5th sunday of Easter. So it is the last possible day of Easter. It is also the anniversary of the founding of [[Lifeism]] in 2011

{{Aries}} Aries 1 is the 113th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 1st day of Aries, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 17, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 5宮1日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 113|Chapter 113]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152133}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 5宮11日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 123|Chapter 123]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152143}}.

{{Aries}} Aries 17 is the 129th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 17th day of Aries, and it is a Wednesday. It corresponds to ISO week 19, weekday 3.
Its informal Japanese name is 5宮17日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 129|Chapter 129]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152149}}.

{{Aries}} Aries 21 is the 133rd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Aries, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 19, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 5宮21日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 133|Chapter 133]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152153}}.

{{Aries}} Aries 28 is the 140th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 28th day of Aries, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 20, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 5宮28日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 140|Chapter 140]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152160}}.

{{Taurus}} Taurus 7 is the 147th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 7th day of Taurus, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 21, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 6宮7日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 147|Chapter 147]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152167}}. Its informal Japanese name is 6宮11日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 151|Chapter 151]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152171}}.

{{Taurus}} Taurus 28 is the 168th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 28th day of Taurus, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 24, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 6宮28日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 168|Chapter 168]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152188}}. Its informal Japanese name is 7宮1日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 169|Chapter 169]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152189}}.

On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 174|Chapter 174]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152194}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152201}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152207}}.

{{Gemini}} Gemini 21 is the 189th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Gemini, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 27, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 7宮21日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 189|Chapter 189]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152209}}. Its informal Japanese name is 7宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 190|Chapter 190]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152210}}.

{{Gemini}} Gemini 27 is the 195th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 27th day of Gemini, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 28, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 7宮27日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 195|Chapter 195]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152215}}.

{{Cancer}} Cancer 1 is the 197th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 1st day of Cancer, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 29, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 8宮1日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 197|Chapter 197]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152217}}.

{{Cancer}} Cancer 3 is the 199th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 3rd day of Cancer, and it is a Wednesday. It corresponds to ISO week 29, weekday 3.
Its informal Japanese name is 8宮3日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 199|Chapter 199]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152219}}.

{{Cancer}} Cancer 14 is the 210th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 14th day of Cancer, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 30, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 8宮14日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 210|Chapter 210]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152230}}.

{{Cancer}} Cancer 22 is the 218th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 22nd day of Cancer, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 32, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 8宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 218|Chapter 218]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152238}}.

{{Leo}} Leo 1 is the 225th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 1st day of Leo, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 33, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 9宮1日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 225|Chapter 225]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152245}}.

{{Leo}} Leo 14 is the 238th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 14th day of Leo, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 34, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 9宮14日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 238|Chapter 238]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152258}}.

{{Leo}} Leo 22 is the 246th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 22nd day of Leo, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 36, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 9宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 246|Chapter 246]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152266}}.

On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 253|Chapter 253]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q153716}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 10宮10日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 262|Chapter 262]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152281}}.

{{Virgo}} Virgo 21 is the 273rd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Virgo, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 39, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 10宮21日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 273|Chapter 273]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152292}}.

{{Libra}} Libra 1 is the 281st day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 1st day of Libra, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 41, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 11宮1日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 281|Chapter 281]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152300}}.

{{Libra}} Libra 14 is the 294th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 14th day of Libra, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 42, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 11宮14日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 294|Chapter 294]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152313}}.

{{Libra}} Libra 21 is the 301st day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Libra, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 43, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 11宮21日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 301|Chapter 301]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152320}}. Its informal Japanese name is 11宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 302|Chapter 302]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152321}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 11宮23日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 303|Chapter 303]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152322}}.

{{Libra}} Libra 27 is the 307th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 27th day of Libra, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 44, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 11宮27日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 307|Chapter 307]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152326}}.

{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 1 is the 309th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 1st day of Scorpio, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 45, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 12宮1日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 309|Chapter 309]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152328}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152330}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152332}}.

To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152334}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 12宮9日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 317|Chapter 317]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152336}}.

{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 11 is the 319th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 11th day of Scorpio, and it is a Thursday. It corresponds to ISO week 46, weekday 4.
Its informal Japanese name is 12宮11日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 319|Chapter 319]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152338}}.

Its informal Japanese name is 12宮13日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 321|Chapter 321]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152340}}.

{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 15 is the 323rd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 15th day of Scorpio, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 47, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 12宮15日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 323|Chapter 323]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152342}}.

{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 17 is the 325th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 17th day of Scorpio, and it is a Wednesday. It corresponds to ISO week 47, weekday 3.
Its informal Japanese name is 12宮17日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 325|Chapter 325]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152344}}.

{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 19 is the 327th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 19th day of Scorpio, and it is a Friday. It corresponds to ISO week 47, weekday 5.
Its informal Japanese name is 12宮19日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 327|Chapter 327]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152346}}.

{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 21 is the 329th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Scorpio, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 47, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 12宮21日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 329|Chapter 329]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152348}}. [[Category:Days with weekday Sunday]] [[Category:Days 21 of the Gaian calendar]] [[Category:Days of Scorpio]] {{DEFAULTSORT:12宮21日}} == Overview == [[:Category:Days_that_Niiname-sai_(新嘗祭)_falls_on|Niiname-sai]] official day Arc comes from [[Capricorn 21]] Celebration of the end of WWII. Culminates with the celebration of the (fictional) Daijosai of 1945.

Its informal Japanese name is 12宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 330|Chapter 330]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152349}}.

{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 23 is the 331st day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 23rd day of Scorpio, and it is a Tuesday. It corresponds to ISO week 48, weekday 2.
Its informal Japanese name is 12宮23日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 331|Chapter 331]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152350}}.

revision.text:
{{Scorpio}} Scorpio 26 is the 334th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 26th day of Scorpio, and it is a Friday. It corresponds to ISO week 48, weekday 5.
Its informal Japanese name is 12宮26日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 334|Chapter 334]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152353}}.
[[Category:Days with weekday Friday]] [[Category:Days 26 of the Gaian calendar]] [[Category:Days of Scorpio]] {{DEFAULTSORT:12宮26日}}

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 16 is the 352nd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 16th day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Tuesday. It corresponds to ISO week 51, weekday 2.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮16日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 352|Chapter 352]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152371}}.

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 17 is the 353rd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 17th day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Wednesday. It corresponds to ISO week 51, weekday 3.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮17日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 353|Chapter 353]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152372}}.

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 19 is the 355th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 19th day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Friday. It corresponds to ISO week 51, weekday 5.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮19日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 355|Chapter 355]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152374}}.

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 21 is the 357th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 21st day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 51, weekday 7. Its informal Japanese name is 13宮21日. On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 357|Chapter 357]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read. To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152376}}. {{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 22 is the 358th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 22nd day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Monday. It corresponds to ISO week 52, weekday 1.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮22日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 358|Chapter 358]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152377}}.

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 23 is the 359th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 23rd day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Tuesday. It corresponds to ISO week 52, weekday 2.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮23日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 359|Chapter 359]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152378}}.

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 25 is the 361st day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 25th day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Thursday. It corresponds to ISO week 52, weekday 4.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮25日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 361|Chapter 361]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152380}}.

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 27 is the 363rd day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 27th day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Saturday. It corresponds to ISO week 52, weekday 6.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮27日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 363|Chapter 363]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152382}}.

{{Ophiuchus}} Ophiuchus 28 is the 364th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is the 28th day of Ophiuchus, and it is a Sunday. It corresponds to ISO week 52, weekday 7.
Its informal Japanese name is 13宮28日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 364|Chapter 364]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152383}}.

{{Horus}} Horus 4 is the 368th day of the year in the [[Gaian calendar]]. It is an intercalary day, the 4th of the 7 days of Horus. It falls on a Thursday in intercalary week 53.
Its informal Japanese name is 14宮4日.
On this day, [[Gaiad chapter 368|Chapter 368]] of the [[Gaiad]] is read.
To see structured data on this date see {{q|Q152387}}.
